Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects (stars, galaxies, planets, etc.) and phenomena that originate outside the Earth's atmosphere. It involves physics, mathematics, and chemistry. Astronomy began with ancient civilizations' observations of the night sky, but modern astronomy started in the 16th century with the invention of the telescope. Today, it uses advanced technology like space telescopes and radio telescopes to gather data from distant galaxies and even the edge of the observable universe. Key areas of study include exoplanets, dark matter, and the Big Bang theory. Astronomy inspires curiosity and contributes to our understanding of the universe and our place in it.

Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects (such as stars, galaxies, planets, and more) and phenomena that originate outside Earth's atmosphere. Recent advancements include detecting exoplanets, studying dark matter, and unraveling the mysteries of black holes. It involves physics, mathematics, and chemistry. Astronomy seeks to understand the nature, properties, and interactions of celestial bodies and the physics of the universe.
